Q2.reasoning: Ordering clinician is a medical geneticist and testing was done with pre-test genetic counseling — meets UHC requirements that a genetics provider or appropriate specialist order/coordinate testing.

Q3.reasoning: UHC criteria list unexplained developmental delay/intellectual disability as an indication for comprehensive genomic testing (WGS/WES); the patient has developmental delay and intellectual disability without a specific syndrome.

Q4.reasoning: UHC typically requires prior first‑line testing (chromosomal microarray and Fragile X for males when indicated) before WGS/WES. Only Fragile X is documented as nondiagnostic; CMA status is not provided, so required prior testing has not been completed.

Q5.reasoning: UHC policies note family history/consanguinity of similar phenotype can support testing. Although there is a family history of Long QT syndrome in the father, this is unrelated to the child’s developmental phenotype and does not constitute relevant family history for neurodevelopmental testing.

Q6.reasoning: UHC commonly requires genetic counseling pre- and post-test. Pre-test counseling was completed and post-test counseling is planned, satisfying counseling requirements.

Q7.reasoning: 81425 corresponds to whole genome sequencing (WGS) interpretation/reporting and is the appropriate CPT among the provided options.

Q8.reasoning: Although the patient meets clinical indication, age, provider, and counseling requirements, UHC requires prior first‑line testing (notably CMA) before WGS; CMA is not documented as completed, so WGS does not meet coverage criteria at this time.
